messages.content: Vasily has a deck of cards consisting of n cards. There is an integer on each of the cards, this integer is between 1 and 100 000, inclusive. It is possible that some cards have the same integers on them. Vasily decided to sort the cards. To do this, he repeatedly takes the top card from the deck, and if the number on it equals the minimum number written on the cards in the deck, then he places the card away. Otherwise, he puts it under the deck and takes the next card from the top, and so on. The process ends as soon as there are no cards in the deck. You can assume that Vasily always knows the minimum number written on some card in the remaining deck, but doesn't know where this card (or these cards) is. You are to determine the total number of times Vasily takes the top card from the deck. Write a function named `count_card_takes` to solve this problem. It must pass ALL these test cases: assert count_card_takes(4, [6, 3, 1, 2]) == 6 assert count_card_takes(7, [3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3]) == 6 assert count_card_takes(1, [1000]) == 1 Provide only the function implementation in Python. Put your solution between ... tags.

response: def count_card_takes(n, cards): # Find the distinct card values in ascending order makespan = sorted(set(cards)) # Map each card value to its index in the makespan rank = {val: idx for idx, val in enumerate(makespan)} # Count how many cards of each value there are freq = [0] * len(makespan) for v in cards: freq[rank[v]] += 1 # Calculate total takes total = 0 zeroes = 0 for c in freq: total += c * zeroes zeroes += c return total

messages.content: Write a function that checks the braces status in a string, and return `True` if all braces are properly closed, or `False` otherwise. Available types of brackets: `()`, `[]`, `{}`. **Please note, you need to write this function without using regex!** Write a function named `braces_status` to solve this problem. It must pass ALL these test cases: assert braces_status('([[some](){text}here]...)') == True assert braces_status('()[]{}()') == False assert braces_status('{([])}') == False assert braces_status('1239(df){') == False assert braces_status('[()])') == False assert braces_status('(...[]...{(..())}[abc]())') == True assert braces_status(')12[x]34(') == False Provide only the function implementation in Python. Put your solution between ... tags.

response: def braces_status(s): """ Check if all types of braces are properly balanced in the string s. Returns True if every opening brace has a matching closing brace in correct order; otherwise returns False. """ stack = [] pairs = {')': '(', ']': '[', '}': '{'} for ch in s: if ch in '([{': stack.append(ch) elif ch in ')]}': if not stack: return False if stack.pop() != pairs[ch]: return False return len(stack) == 0

errors: Test braces_status('()[]{}()') failed: Expected False, got True
Test braces_status('{([])}') failed: Expected False, got True

messages.content: Finally, a basketball court has been opened in SIS, so Demid has decided to hold a basketball exercise session. 2·n students have come to Demid's exercise session, and he lined up them into two rows of the same size (there are exactly n people in each row). Students are numbered from 1 to n in each row in order from left to right. Now Demid wants to choose a team to play basketball. He will choose players from left to right, and the index of each chosen player (excluding the first one taken) will be strictly greater than the index of the previously chosen player. To avoid giving preference to one of the rows, Demid chooses students in such a way that no consecutive chosen students belong to the same row. The first student can be chosen among all 2n students (there are no additional constraints), and a team can consist of any number of students. Demid thinks, that in order to compose a perfect team, he should choose students in such a way, that the total height of all chosen students is maximum possible. Help Demid to find the maximum possible total height of players in a team he can choose. Write a function named `max_team_height` to solve this problem. It must pass ALL these test cases: assert max_team_height(1, [7], [4]) == 4 assert max_team_height(3, [1, 2, 9], [10, 1, 1]) == 19 assert max_team_height(5, [9, 3, 5, 7, 3], [5, 8, 1, 4, 5]) == 28 Provide only the function implementation in Python. Put your solution between ... tags.

response: def max_team_height(n, a, b): """ Given two lists a and b of length n, representing the heights of students in two rows, returns the maximum total height of a team chosen under these rules: - Students are chosen in increasing order of their column index. - No two consecutive chosen students are in the same row. - The team can start with any student. """ # Initialize accumulated sums: sa[i] = sum of a[0..i-1], sb[i] = sum of b[0..i-1] sa = [0] * (n + 1) sb = [0] * (n + 1) for i in range(1, n + 1): sa[i] = sa[i - 1] + a[i - 1] sb[i] = sb[i - 1] + b[i - 1] # dp0[i] = max sum ending at a[i-1], dp1[i] = max sum ending at b[i-1] dp0 = [float('-inf')] * (n + 1) dp1 = [float('-inf')] * (n + 1) dp0[0] = 0 dp1[0] = 0 # Renown dynamic programming: # For each position, you either skip or take it (shifting from the opposite row of the last chosen student) for i in range(1, n + 1): dp0[i] = max(dp0[i - 1], dp1[i - 1] + a[i - 1]) # last on row a dp1[i] = max(dp1[i - 1], dp0[i - 1] + b[i - 1]) # last on row b # The answer is the best possible ending at either row up to position n return max(dp0[n], dp1[n])

messages.content: In this kata, your task is to create a function that takes a single list as an argument and returns a flattened list. The input list will have a maximum of one level of nesting (list(s) inside of a list). ```python # no nesting [1, 2, 3] # one level of nesting [1, [2, 3]] ``` Write a function named `flatten_me` to solve this problem. It must pass ALL these test cases: assert flatten_me([1, [2, 3], 4]) == [1, 2, 3, 4] assert flatten_me([[True, False], ['!'], ['?'], [71, '@']]) == [True, False, '!', '?', 71] assert flatten_me([['a', 'b'], 'c', ['d']]) == ['a', 'b', 'c', ['d']] assert flatten_me(['!', '?']) == ['!', '?'] Provide only the function implementation in Python. Put your solution between ... tags.

response: def flatten_me(lst): """ Flattens a list with at most one level of nested lists. """ if lst and isinstance(lst[0], list): result = [] for sub in lst: if isinstance(sub, list): result.extend(sub) else: result.append(sub) return result return lst

errors: Test flatten_me([[True, False], ['!'], ['?'], [71, '@']]) failed: Expected [True, False, '!', '?', 71], got [True, False, '!', '?', 71, '@']
